name: Boeing 777-200LR Worldliner
description: The Boeing 777-200LR Worldliner is the longest-range commercial aircraft ever built, capable of flying 9,395 nautical miles nonstop. First delivered in 2006, it features GE90-115BL engines (the most powerful jet engines ever built), raked wingtips for improved fuel efficiency, and three optional auxiliary fuel tanks in the aft cargo hold. The 777-200LR set a world record in 2005 by flying eastbound from Hong Kong to London, the longest nonstop flight by a commercial aircraft at that time.

zones.name: Cockpit
zones.description: The 777-200LR flight deck features the same fly-by-wire glass cockpit as other 777 variants, with additional fuel management displays for the auxiliary tank system.

zones.name: Forward Galley
zones.description: The forward galley provisioned for ultra-long-haul flights exceeding 17 hours, with enhanced catering storage.

zones.name: Forward Lavatory
zones.description: Forward lavatories near the premium cabin, designed for extended service on ultra-long-haul routes.

zones.name: Forward Vestibule
zones.description: The forward entry vestibule at door 1L/1R.

zones.name: Forward Cabin Left Seats
zones.description: Left window and middle seats in the forward cabin, configured for premium passengers on ultra-long-haul routes. The Worldliner's lower passenger count allows more generous seating along the port side.

zones.name: Forward Cabin Left Aisle
zones.description: The left aisle of the forward cabin, one of the twin aisles serving the premium class section on flights lasting up to 19 hours.

zones.name: Forward Cabin Center Seats
zones.description: Center seats in the forward cabin between the twin aisles. On the Worldliner, generous business class configurations provide maximum comfort for the longest nonstop flights in aviation.

zones.name: Forward Cabin Right Aisle
zones.description: The right aisle of the forward cabin, providing a second service path through the premium section on ultra-long-haul operations.

zones.name: Forward Cabin Right Seats
zones.description: Right window and middle seats in the forward cabin, mirroring the left side premium seating. Window seats offer views of multiple continents on the Worldliner's globe-spanning routes.

zones.name: Mid Cabin Left Seats
zones.description: Left seat section in the mid cabin. The Worldliner typically seats fewer passengers than other 777-200 variants, so this section may feel less crowded on ultra-long-haul flights.

zones.name: Mid Cabin Left Aisle
zones.description: The left aisle of the mid cabin, running over the wing box that houses the main fuel tanks enabling the Worldliner's extraordinary range.

zones.name: Mid Cabin Center Seats
zones.description: Center seats in the mid cabin between the twin aisles. With the Worldliner's reduced passenger count, some airlines configure enhanced seat pitch for ultra-long-haul comfort.

zones.name: Mid Cabin Right Aisle
zones.description: The right aisle of the mid cabin, used for meal and beverage service on flights lasting nearly a full day.

zones.name: Mid Cabin Right Seats
zones.description: Right seat section in the mid cabin, with economy seating along the starboard side. Window seats offer views over the raked-wingtip wing during ultra-long flights.

zones.name: Aft Cabin Left Seats
zones.description: Left seat section in the aft cabin with reduced seating capacity compared to other 777-200 variants. The Worldliner prioritizes range over passenger density.

zones.name: Aft Cabin Left Aisle
zones.description: The left aisle of the aft cabin, connecting the mid cabin to the aft vestibule on ultra-long-haul routes.

zones.name: Aft Cabin Center Seats
zones.description: Center seats in the aft cabin between the twin aisles. Beneath this section, auxiliary fuel tanks in the cargo hold enable the aircraft's record-breaking range.

zones.name: Aft Cabin Right Aisle
zones.description: The right aisle of the aft cabin, providing access to the rear doors and galley on flights spanning nearly 20 hours.

zones.name: Aft Cabin Right Seats
zones.description: Right seat section in the aft cabin, mirroring the port side. Window seats here offer aft views toward the horizontal stabilizer during the Worldliner's hemisphere-spanning flights.

zones.name: Aft Vestibule
zones.description: The aft entry vestibule with rear boarding doors.

zones.name: Aft Galley
zones.description: The aft galley with provisions for multiple meal services on ultra-long-haul flights.

zones.name: Aft Lavatory
zones.description: Aft lavatories serving the economy cabin on routes lasting up to 19 hours.

zones.name: Forward Cargo Hold
zones.description: The forward lower-deck cargo hold beneath the forward cabin. On the Worldliner, this hold retains full cargo capacity while auxiliary fuel tanks are installed in the aft hold.

zones.name: Aft Cargo Hold
zones.description: The aft lower-deck cargo hold, which on the Worldliner can house up to three auxiliary fuel tanks displacing cargo capacity but extending range beyond 9,000 nautical miles.

zones.name: Bulk Cargo Hold
zones.description: The bulk cargo compartment at the rear of the lower deck, used for loose-loaded baggage on ultra-long-haul routes where cargo capacity is reduced by auxiliary fuel tanks.

zones.name: Cargo Access
zones.description: The forward cargo access passage connecting the main deck to the lower cargo holds for ground loading operations.

zones.name: Nose
zones.description: The nose section with weather radar and avionics, identical to other 777-200 variants.

zones.name: Forward Fuselage
zones.description: The forward lower fuselage with forward cargo hold.

zones.name: Mid Fuselage
zones.description: The center lower fuselage with wing box structure, center fuel tank, and additional fuel plumbing for the auxiliary tank system.

zones.name: Aft Fuselage
zones.description: The aft lower fuselage. Up to three auxiliary fuel tanks can be installed in the aft cargo hold, displacing cargo capacity but extending range to over 9,000 nm.

zones.name: Tail
zones.description: The tail section with APU and empennage structures.

zones.name: Left Wing
zones.description: The port wing with raked wingtips extending the wingspan to 64.8m, improving fuel efficiency by reducing induced drag. The raked tips are a distinguishing feature of the LR and 300ER variants.

zones.name: Right Wing
zones.description: The starboard wing with raked wingtips, matching the port wing configuration.

zones.name: Left Engine
zones.description: The left GE90-115BL engine rated at 115,540 lbs of thrust, the most powerful jet engine ever certified. The 'L' designates the LR-specific variant.

zones.name: Right Engine
zones.description: The right GE90-115BL engine, identical to the left. Together these engines provide the thrust needed for ultra-long-range operations at maximum weight.

zones.name: Left Main Gear
zones.description: The left six-wheel bogie strengthened for the LR's maximum takeoff weight of 347,450 kg.

zones.name: Right Main Gear
zones.description: The right six-wheel bogie, identical to the left.

zones.name: Nose Gear
zones.description: The steerable nose gear with dual wheels.

zones.name: Vertical Stabilizer
zones.description: The vertical stabilizer identical to other 777 variants.

zones.name: Horizontal Stabilizer
zones.description: The trimmable horizontal stabilizer with elevators.

zones.name: APU
zones.description: The Honeywell 331-500 APU essential for ETOPS-330 dispatch requirements on ultra-long-haul routes.

components.name: Captain's Control Column
components.description: The captain's fly-by-wire control column, identical to other 777 variants.
components.interactionText: Grasp the captain's yoke. Fly-by-wire converts inputs to electronic signals for the flight computers.

components.name: First Officer's Control Column
components.description: The first officer's fly-by-wire control column.
components.interactionText: The first officer's yoke provides independent fly-by-wire authority.

components.name: Throttle Quadrant
components.description: Twin thrust levers for the GE90-115BL engines, the most powerful jet engines ever built.
components.interactionText: Command the world's most powerful jet engines. Each GE90-115BL produces over 115,000 lbs of thrust at maximum power.

components.name: Rudder Pedals
components.description: Fly-by-wire rudder pedals with speed-dependent authority.
components.interactionText: Rudder pedals with automatic authority reduction at higher speeds.

components.name: Primary Flight Display (PFD)
components.description: Large-format PFD with full flight data integration.
components.interactionText: The PFD displays attitude, speeds, altitude, heading, and flight modes.

components.name: Navigation Display (ND)
components.description: Navigation display essential for ultra-long-range oceanic and polar route navigation.
components.interactionText: View routes spanning entire hemispheres with ETOPS-330 alternate airports displayed along the way.

components.name: Engine Indicating and Crew Alerting System
components.description: EICAS monitoring the GE90-115BL engines and auxiliary fuel tank system status.
components.interactionText: Monitor the GE90-115BL engine parameters and auxiliary fuel tank transfer status.

components.name: Overhead Panel
components.description: Systems panel with additional controls for the auxiliary fuel tank transfer system unique to the LR variant.
components.interactionText: The overhead panel includes auxiliary fuel tank pump controls for managing fuel transfer from the cargo hold tanks.

components.name: Mode Control Panel (MCP)
components.description: Autopilot interface for managing ultra-long-range flight profiles with multiple step climbs.
components.interactionText: Program step climbs as fuel burns off during 17+ hour flights to maintain optimal cruise altitude.

components.name: Flight Management Computer (FMC)
components.description: Triple-redundant FMC with ETOPS-330 and polar navigation capability for the world's longest nonstop routes.
components.interactionText: Program routes spanning entire hemispheres. The FMC manages ETOPS-330 alternate airports and polar route waypoints.

components.name: Forward Left Entry Door (1L)
components.description: The main wide-body boarding door with dual-lane evacuation slide.
components.interactionText: The main boarding door for the Worldliner, identical to other 777 variants.

components.name: Aft Left Entry Door (4L)
components.description: The aft left entry door for rear boarding and emergency evacuation.
components.interactionText: The aft door for passenger operations.

components.name: Forward Galley Unit
components.description: Premium class galley with extended provisions for ultra-long-haul operations exceeding 17 hours.
components.interactionText: The galley stocks provisions for up to three full meal services and continuous snack availability on ultra-long flights.

components.name: Aft Galley Unit
components.description: The aft galley serving economy class on ultra-long-haul routes.
components.interactionText: Extended catering storage for flights lasting nearly a full day.

components.name: Overhead Storage Bins
components.description: Wide-body overhead bins across three rows.
components.interactionText: Three rows of bins provide ample storage for the Worldliner's typically lower passenger count.

components.name: Row 1 Business Class Seats
components.description: Premium seating designed for maximum comfort on the world's longest nonstop routes.
components.interactionText: Business class seats on the Worldliner feature lie-flat beds essential for flights lasting 17+ hours.

components.name: Forward Cabin Business Class Seats
components.description: Premium business class seats on the Worldliner, configured for the longest nonstop flights in commercial aviation. With routes exceeding 17 hours, these seats are designed for maximum rest with full lie-flat capability and enhanced personal space.
components.interactionText: Sit in a Worldliner business class seat designed for ultra-long-haul comfort. The fully flat bed and direct aisle access are essential on 17-plus hour flights. Find the large entertainment screen, multiple power outlets, and personal storage compartment.

components.name: Mid Cabin Economy Seats
components.description: Economy seats in the mid cabin of the 777-200LR Worldliner. With fewer total passengers than other 777-200 variants due to auxiliary fuel tanks, the mid cabin may feel less crowded. Seats are configured for ultra-long-haul comfort with enhanced pitch on some airlines.
components.interactionText: Sit in a mid cabin economy seat on the Worldliner. This aircraft can fly over 17 hours nonstop. The reduced passenger count means a potentially quieter cabin. Check the entertainment system, designed with extra content for ultra-long flights.

components.name: Aft Cabin Economy Seats
components.description: Aft economy seats on the 777-200LR. Beneath this section, auxiliary fuel tanks in the cargo hold enable the aircraft's record-breaking range of over 9,400 nautical miles. The reduced passenger capacity means fewer seats in this section compared to the standard 777-200.
components.interactionText: Sit in an aft cabin seat on the Worldliner. The auxiliary fuel tanks below enable flights like New York to Singapore. Check the seatback screen, overhead bin, and safety card.

components.name: Forward Cabin Left Overhead Bins
components.description: Overhead storage bins above the left seats in the forward cabin. With the Worldliner's lower passenger count, bins are less likely to fill up.
components.interactionText: Open the left overhead bin in the forward cabin. The Worldliner's reduced passenger count means more overhead space per passenger.

components.name: Forward Cabin Right Overhead Bins
components.description: Overhead storage bins above the right seats in the forward cabin, mirroring the left side.
components.interactionText: Open the right overhead bin in the forward cabin. Premium class passengers on the Worldliner have generous overhead storage.

components.name: Mid Cabin Left Overhead Bins
components.description: Overhead storage bins above the left seats in the mid cabin over the wing section.
components.interactionText: Open the left overhead bin in the mid cabin. These bins serve passengers on the port side of the Worldliner.

components.name: Mid Cabin Right Overhead Bins
components.description: Overhead storage bins above the right seats in the mid cabin.
components.interactionText: Open the right overhead bin in the mid cabin. Starboard bins serve passengers on the right side of the aircraft.

components.name: Aft Cabin Left Overhead Bins
components.description: Overhead storage bins above the left seats in the aft economy cabin on ultra-long-haul routes.
components.interactionText: Open the left overhead bin in the aft cabin. With fewer passengers on the Worldliner, aft bins typically have space available.

components.name: Aft Cabin Right Overhead Bins
components.description: Overhead storage bins above the right seats in the aft economy cabin.
components.interactionText: Open the right overhead bin in the aft cabin. The last bins before the aft vestibule on the Worldliner.

components.name: Forward Cabin Left Window
components.description: A cabin window on the left side of the forward cabin, offering views across multiple continents on the Worldliner's globe-spanning routes.
components.interactionText: Look through the forward cabin left window. On the Worldliner's ultra-long-haul routes, you may cross multiple oceans and continents in a single flight.

components.name: Forward Cabin Right Window
components.description: A cabin window on the right side of the forward cabin, providing views on routes that can span nearly half the globe.
components.interactionText: Look through the forward cabin right window. The 777's larger windows offer generous views on flights that can last nearly 20 hours.

components.name: Mid Cabin Left Window
components.description: A cabin window on the left side of the mid cabin over the wing, with views of the GE90-115BL engine and raked wingtips.
components.interactionText: Look through the mid cabin left window over the wing. The massive GE90-115BL engine nacelle is visible, along with the distinctive raked wingtips unique to the LR.

components.name: Mid Cabin Right Window
components.description: A cabin window on the right side of the mid cabin with views over the starboard wing and its raked wingtip.
components.interactionText: Look through the mid cabin right window. The right GE90-115BL engine and raked wingtip are visible on the extended-span wing.

components.name: Aft Cabin Left Window
components.description: A cabin window on the left side of the aft cabin, offering views of the wing trailing edge during ultra-long flights.
components.interactionText: Look through the aft cabin left window. On a 17-hour Worldliner flight, watch the sun set and rise again as you cross time zones and hemispheres.

components.name: Aft Cabin Right Window
components.description: A cabin window on the right side of the aft cabin with views toward the horizontal stabilizer on the world's longest flights.
components.interactionText: Look through the aft cabin right window on the Worldliner. The horizontal stabilizer is visible aft as the aircraft crosses the globe.

components.name: Forward Exit Row Seats
components.description: Exit row seats in the forward cabin with extra legroom. On the Worldliner's ultra-long flights of 17+ hours, the additional space is highly prized.
components.interactionText: Sit in the forward exit row seat. On a 17-hour Worldliner flight, the extra legroom is invaluable. Read the exit row safety briefing card.

components.name: Forward Cabin Window Seat
components.description: A window seat in the forward business class cabin on the Worldliner, with panoramic views on routes spanning nearly half the globe.
components.interactionText: Sit in a Worldliner forward cabin window seat. On ultra-long-haul routes, you may see multiple sunrises and sunsets through this window.

components.name: Forward Cabin Center Seat
components.description: A center section seat in the forward business class cabin on the Worldliner, positioned between the twin aisles for easy access on ultra-long flights.
components.interactionText: Sit in a Worldliner center seat with direct aisle access from both sides. Privacy partitions create a personal suite for the 17+ hour journey.

components.name: Mid Cabin Exit Row Seats
components.description: Exit row seats at the overwing exits in the mid cabin of the Worldliner, offering the most legroom in economy for ultra-long flights.
components.interactionText: Sit in the overwing exit row on the Worldliner. On flights lasting nearly 20 hours, this extra legroom is a significant advantage. Review the exit row briefing card.

components.name: Mid Cabin Window Seat
components.description: A window seat in the mid cabin over the wing, with views of the world's most powerful jet engine and the raked wingtips unique to the Worldliner.
components.interactionText: Sit in a mid cabin window seat over the wing. The massive GE90-115BL engine is visible ahead, and the distinctive raked wingtips extend beyond the wing.

components.name: Mid Cabin Center Seat
components.description: A center section seat in the mid cabin economy class of the Worldliner. The reduced passenger count may mean an empty middle seat beside you on some routes.
components.interactionText: Sit in a center economy seat on the Worldliner. The entertainment system has extensive content for ultra-long flights, and the twin aisles provide easy movement.

components.name: Aft Cabin Exit Row Seats
components.description: Exit row seats in the aft cabin of the Worldliner near the rear emergency exits, with extra legroom for ultra-long flights.
components.interactionText: Sit in the aft exit row on the Worldliner. The extra legroom is especially welcome on flights lasting up to 19 hours. Review the exit operation procedure.

components.name: Aft Cabin Window Seat
components.description: A window seat in the aft economy cabin of the Worldliner. Beneath this section, auxiliary fuel tanks enable the record-breaking range.
components.interactionText: Sit in an aft cabin window seat on the Worldliner. Below you, auxiliary fuel tanks hold the fuel for this globe-spanning flight. Watch the world scroll by.

components.name: Last Row Economy Seat
components.description: The very last row of economy seats on the Worldliner. Limited recline but closest to rear facilities, useful on ultra-long flights lasting up to 19 hours.
components.interactionText: Sit in the last row on the Worldliner. Limited recline, but easy access to lavatories and the galley for snacks on this nearly 20-hour flight.

components.name: Forward Cargo LD3 Containers
components.description: LD3 unit load devices in the forward cargo hold. The Worldliner's forward hold retains full cargo capacity while auxiliary fuel tanks occupy the aft hold.
components.interactionText: Examine the LD3 containers in the forward hold. On the Worldliner, the forward hold carries most of the cargo since the aft hold may contain auxiliary fuel tanks.

components.name: Forward Cargo Restraint Net
components.description: The cargo restraint net system in the forward hold, securing LD3 containers during ultra-long flights that may encounter turbulence across multiple weather systems.
components.interactionText: Inspect the cargo net restraint system. Heavy-duty nets secure containers against the 9g forward load requirement during the Worldliner's long flights.

components.name: Forward Cargo Door
components.description: The powered forward cargo door providing access to the forward lower-deck cargo hold, the primary cargo compartment on the Worldliner.
components.interactionText: Examine the forward cargo door. On the Worldliner, this door accesses the main cargo hold since the aft hold may house auxiliary fuel tanks.

components.name: Aft Cargo LD3 Containers
components.description: LD3 containers in the aft cargo hold. On the Worldliner, up to three auxiliary fuel tanks can replace cargo containers in this hold, reducing cargo capacity but extending range beyond 9,000 nm.
components.interactionText: Examine the aft hold. When auxiliary fuel tanks are installed here, cargo capacity is reduced but the Worldliner achieves its record-breaking range.

components.name: Aft Cargo Restraint Net
components.description: The cargo restraint system in the aft hold, which must also secure auxiliary fuel tanks when installed for ultra-long-range operations.
components.interactionText: Inspect the aft cargo restraints. When auxiliary fuel tanks are installed, specialized fittings secure the heavy tanks in place of standard cargo containers.

components.name: Aft Cargo Door
components.description: The powered aft cargo door. On the Worldliner, this door also provides access for installing and removing auxiliary fuel tanks.
components.interactionText: Examine the aft cargo door. Auxiliary fuel tanks are loaded through this door when configuring the Worldliner for its longest routes.

components.name: Bulk Cargo Loading Area
components.description: The bulk cargo compartment at the rear of the lower deck, used for loose-loaded baggage on the Worldliner's ultra-long-haul routes.
components.interactionText: Examine the bulk cargo area. On the Worldliner, this compartment handles overflow baggage when the aft hold is occupied by auxiliary fuel tanks.

components.name: Left GE90-115BL Engine
components.description: The left GE90-115BL produces 115,540 lbs of thrust, making it the most powerful jet engine ever certified. The 134-inch fan is the world's largest.
components.interactionText: The GE90-115BL holds the world record for thrust. Its 134-inch fan with composite blades produces over 115,000 lbs of thrust.

components.name: Right GE90-115BL Engine
components.description: The right GE90-115BL, identical to the left. The 'L' suffix denotes the LR-specific engine variant.
components.interactionText: Each GE90-115BL consumes fuel at roughly 3,600 kg/hour at cruise, enabling the Worldliner's extraordinary range.

components.name: Nose Landing Gear Assembly
components.description: The nose gear with dual wheels for the ultra-long-range variant.
components.interactionText: The nose gear is identical to other 777 variants.

components.name: Left Main Landing Gear
components.description: The left six-wheel bogie rated for the LR's 347,450 kg maximum takeoff weight, the heaviest of any 777-200 variant.
components.interactionText: The main gear supports the Worldliner's high takeoff weight fully loaded with fuel for 19-hour flights.

components.name: Right Main Landing Gear
components.description: The right six-wheel bogie, identical to the left.
components.interactionText: Six wheels distribute the enormous takeoff weight across the runway surface.

components.name: Left Aileron
components.description: The left fly-by-wire aileron, with the wing extended by raked wingtips.
components.interactionText: The aileron is positioned inboard of the raked wingtips that extend the wingspan to 64.8 meters.

components.name: Right Aileron
components.description: The right fly-by-wire aileron on the extended-span wing.
components.interactionText: The right aileron works opposite to the left for roll control on the extended wing.

components.name: Left Trailing Edge Flaps
components.description: Single-slotted Fowler flaps and flaperon on the left wing.
components.interactionText: Fowler flaps extend on tracks. Flaperons provide combined flap and aileron function.

components.name: Right Trailing Edge Flaps
components.description: Single-slotted Fowler flaps and flaperon on the right wing.
components.interactionText: Right flaps deploy symmetrically with the left for balanced lift.

components.name: Left Leading Edge Slats
components.description: Full-span slats on the left wing of the extended-span design.
components.interactionText: Full-span slats work with the raked wingtip design to maximize low-speed lift performance.

components.name: Right Leading Edge Slats
components.description: Full-span slats on the right wing.
components.interactionText: Symmetric slat deployment for balanced lift augmentation.

components.name: Elevator
components.description: Fly-by-wire elevators with pitch envelope protection.
components.interactionText: Fly-by-wire elevators with envelope protection against excessive pitch attitudes.

components.name: Rudder
components.description: Fly-by-wire rudder with triple-redundant actuators for ETOPS-330 reliability.
components.interactionText: Triple-redundant rudder actuators ensure reliability for ETOPS-330 operations up to 5.5 hours from a diversion airport.

components.name: Wing Spoilers / Speed Brakes
components.description: Fly-by-wire spoiler panels for speed brakes and roll augmentation.
components.interactionText: Spoilers manage descent rate and augment roll control on the extended-span wings.

components.name: Weather Radar Antenna
components.description: Advanced weather radar for ultra-long-range route weather detection across remote oceanic and polar regions.
components.interactionText: The weather radar detects weather hundreds of miles ahead on routes crossing remote oceanic and polar regions.

components.name: APU Exhaust
components.description: The Honeywell 331-500 APU essential for ETOPS-330 dispatch on the world's longest routes.
components.interactionText: The APU must be serviceable for ETOPS-330 dispatch, the highest ETOPS rating achieved by the 777.

controlSurfaces.name: Ailerons
controlSurfaces.movementDescription: Yoke turned: fly-by-wire commands aileron deflection on the extended-span wings with raked wingtips.
controlSurfaces.flightEffect: Roll control with envelope protection. The raked wingtips improve roll damping characteristics.

controlSurfaces.name: Elevator
controlSurfaces.movementDescription: Yoke pulled back: elevators up. Pushed forward: elevators down.
controlSurfaces.flightEffect: Pitch control with envelope protection against stall and overspeed.

controlSurfaces.name: Rudder
controlSurfaces.movementDescription: Left pedal: rudder left. Right pedal: rudder right. Speed-dependent authority limiting.
controlSurfaces.flightEffect: Yaw control essential for single-engine operations during ETOPS-330 diversion scenarios.

controlSurfaces.name: Trailing Edge Flaps
controlSurfaces.movementDescription: Flap lever positions: UP, 1, 5, 15, 20, 25, 30. Fowler flaps extend on tracks.
controlSurfaces.flightEffect: Flap extension provides critical lift augmentation for heavy-weight takeoffs on the highest MTOW 777-200 variant.

controlSurfaces.name: Leading Edge Slats
controlSurfaces.movementDescription: Full-span slats deploy automatically with flap selection.
controlSurfaces.flightEffect: Slats increase maximum angle of attack for safe approach speeds at the LR's high landing weights.

controlSurfaces.name: Spoilers / Speed Brakes
controlSurfaces.movementDescription: Speedbrake lever: symmetric deployment. Roll input: asymmetric deployment.
controlSurfaces.flightEffect: Speed brakes manage descent. Ground spoilers deploy on landing for maximum braking effectiveness.

controlSurfaces.name: Flaperons
controlSurfaces.movementDescription: Flaperons droop with flap extension and deflect differentially for roll control.
controlSurfaces.flightEffect: Combined flap and aileron function optimized for the extended-span wing design.
